summary: A letter from defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim to Judge J. Nathan regarding the conditions of Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial detention at the Metropolitan Detention Center. The letter disputes government claims that Maxwell used a cart to barricade a door and argues that fluctuating restrictions on her access to legal materials hinder her trial preparation.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell and disputing government claims about Maxwell's conduct and detention conditions.

persons.name: J. Nathan
persons.context: Recipient of the letter, presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case, whose detention conditions and access to legal materials for trial preparation are the subject of the letter.

connections.description: Sternheim is the defense attorney representing Maxwell, as evidenced by her filing this letter on Maxwell's behalf.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Defense Letter on Detention Conditions
events.description: Defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim files a letter with the court disputing government allegations about Maxwell's conduct and arguing that restrictions on her access to legal materials hinder trial preparation.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense disputes a government claim that Ghislaine Maxwell used a cart to barricade the door to a Video Teleconference (VTC) room, stating the cart was never used for that purpose.
Maxwell's access to legal materials for VTC sessions is restricted and fluctuates based on rules set by rotating guard teams at the MDC.
The defense argues these restrictions impact the productivity of legal conferences and compromise Maxwell's ability to prepare for trial.
The letter frames the government's allegations as an attempt to justify existing restrictions on Maxwell's legal material access.
